settings.title: What is eye irritation?
settings.text: Eye irritation is a common symptom of allergies and hay fever where the eyes become itchy, red or watery. When pollen comes into contact with the eyes of people who are sensitive, a condition called 'hayfever eyes' or seasonal allergic conjunctivitis occurs.

settings.title: How can you treat eye irritation?
settings.text: Eye drops are the most common way to treat the symptoms of eye irritation. These eye drops will often contain antihistamines or anti-inflammatories that work to reduce the immune responses which are causing the unpleasant symptoms.

settings.title: How long does it take for an eye irritation to go away?
settings.text: Depending on the eye infection, treatment time varies. Viral infections can be cleared up in 1-2 weeks. Bacterial infections can last for a few days. Other eye irritation can be resolved within the same day if it is caused by allergies.

settings.title: Can allergy eye drops be used daily?
settings.text: Allergy eye drops should not be used daily unless directed by the doctor. Allergy eye drops are meant for short term usage.

settings.title: Are allergy eye drops good for your eyes?
settings.text: Allergy eye drops contain antihistamines that will block the histamine causing allergic symptoms such as eye irritation or redness. They also help to treat dry eyes.

settings.title: What are eye drops for allergic conjunctivitis?
settings.text: Chloramphenicol is usually the first line of antibiotic treatment for conjunctivitis. Doctors may prescribe eye drops or tablets.

settings.text: An online consultation checks if you are eligible to purchase the product.
